review.title: Using Clustering to extract Personality Information from socio economic data
review.abstract: It has become apparent that models that have been applied widely in economics, including Machine Learning techniques and Data Mining methods, should take into consideration principles that derive from the theories of Personality Psychology in order to discover more comprehensive knowledge regarding complicated economic behaviours. In this work, we present a method to extract Behavioural Groups by using simple clustering techniques that can potentially reveal aspects of the Personalities for their members. We believe that this is very important because the psychological information regarding the Personalities of individuals is limited in real world applications and because it can become a useful tool in improving the traditional models of Knowledge Economy.
histories: UKCI 2012, the 12th Annual Workshop on Computational Intelligence, Heriot-Watt University, 2012
review.COMMENTS: UKCI 2012, the 12th Annual Workshop on Computational Intelligence, Heriot-Watt University, 2012

metadata.title: Using Clustering to extract Personality Information from socio economic data

sections.text: This year, it is only a matter of time before agreement is reached.

sections.heading: A. Data Analysis
sections.text: The CCCS dataset introduced in [3] is a cross-sectional socio-economic dataset based on data from the Consumer Credit Advisory Service. In its 58 attributes, it contains information about 70,000 customers who contacted the Service between 2004 and 2008 to receive advice on how to overcome their debts. Information was gathered through interviews when each customer first contacted the Service, and it varies from the standard demographic of financial details, spending details and debt details. Based on this fact, we can see that the 58 attributes of the dataset are organized into more general categories of attributes such as the above. They form a sort of hierarchy, shown in Figure 2. Here, the CCCS dataset is divided into 6 broad categories, demographics, debt, assets, expenses, debit details and income. This is similar to the above, the only difference being that financial details are divided into income and assets and unsecured assets and information about debt.

sections.heading: B. Data preprocessing
sections.text: Before moving into the cluster analysis of the data, it is always important to analyze them, find inconsistencies within the data and provide a way to deal with them. In the CCCS dataset, there were a lot of problems before clustering the data in terms of missing values, nominal attributes, duplicates, correlations and a decision about whether we should consider the time parameter. The problems that came to our attention and the measures we have taken to deal with them are the following: Missing attributes. Although the percentage of missing values contains about 18% of the data, they tend to appear in the same clients for the same type of categories. In this sense, we were able to delete the specific clients in terms of the attributes that we were interested in and move to a smaller dataset with a very small percentage of missing values. In the case of using all the attributes, we were able to reduce the size of the dataset to about 37000 with a percentage of 0.8% missing values.

sections.heading: C. Data Description of CCCS attributes
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: A. Biplots
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: C. Selfish/ Non Selfish Characterization
sections.text: In an attempt to associate the behavioural groups we discovered with aspects of personality, we processed the selfishness ratings to produce a ranking of the spending attributes as to how strongly they are associated with the Selfish Personality. To achieve this, we calculated a weight of how strongly the individual attributes define the Selfish Personality for each of the attributes we subtracted from the Selfish Method. Finally, weights were normalized and evaluated in descending order. Attributes with their final weights can be subtracted in Table 6 and we can easily see that the attributes Leisure, Travel and Foodare strongly associated with the Selfish Personality.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
sections.text: We would like to thank John Gathergood, Lecturer at the School of Economics, for providing the CCCS dataset and the 52 students in the Department of Psychology for voluntarily participating in the expenditure evaluation.

referenceMentions.context: From Personality Psychology and Economics’ perspective [4] it is emphasized that information regarding the Personality, when applied in a theoretically meaningful way, can provide further insight in interpreting complexities and patterns of economic behaviour.

From Computer Science perspective, particularly in Behavior Mining as it is defined in [11], the procedures of Data Mining and Machine Learning must take into consideration the semantics of the data, which within the economic context can be Personality characteristics that govern the transactional data.
In [6] behaviour is defined as the action or reaction of an entity to stimuli in environment.

A very interesting and innovative overview of this work is provided by [1] and [4] where they present models to measure Personality within economic context and they show how the models from Economics can benefit from the models of Psychology and vice versa.

In particular, in [4] the authors state that the economic modeling of preferences would benefit from the application of psychometric principles and that Personality Information can provide alternative ways of research in Economics, introducing a theoretical background of explaining anti-social traits, an area of Personality Psychology that was undermined by traditional economic analyses.
From a computer science perspective, Behaviour Informatics defined in [6], offer a way to mine behaviours from the data in order to provide a deep understanding of behaviours.
The same basic idea is demonstrated in [10] where a mining approach similar to A-priori is performed in stock market data in order to find peculiarity groups.
Finally, the field of Behavior mining introduced in [11] can provide some interesting and innovative ideas about how we can proceed with the construction of our model, depicted in Fig 1.
In more detail, [11] defines a new field of Data Mining, namely Behavior Mining, in which the semantics of the data should be taken into consideration.

Moreover we think that the proposed framework of behavioural data in [11] to encapsulate the semantics in our data, increases the complexity of the analysis and it cancels out traditional and powerful methods of Data Mining which perform on simple data and not complex.
The CCCS dataset, introduced in [3], is a socioeconomic crossectional dataset based on the data provided by the Consumer Credit Counseling Service.

Although this assumption is valid for almost all attributes except debt, which as stated in [3] is being reduced in a steady rate over time, we decided to not to consider the time parameter after all because it needs a time series analysis which is very different from the purposes of this work.
Further information of this algorithm can be found in [7].
Clara on the other hand, introduced on [5], is appropriate for clustering large applications.

Then we utilized the Silhouette criterion [8] for the case of Clara and Calinski Index [2] for the case of Kmeans to help us identify good clusterings, since both of them return a value indicating how well separated and compact the clusters are.
